comments.text:
+nancy carter Hi Nancy, unfortunately a blender won't work for the pastry, 
BUT you can do it by hand. Put all the dry ingredients into a bowl and rub 
in the butter with your hands or a fork until it remembers bread crumbs. 
Hope this helps :)

top_comment.text:
Why do you have to make the corn starch warm? I heard that if you add 
something hot to corn starch it starts clumping?? ﻿
top_comment.author: Cute Addiction

comments.text:
Thank you 
Today I'm going to make lemon Meringue pie 
I'm so exited >.< :D xoxox
Thank you for the recipe
comments.author: Cute Addiction

comments.text:
+Nadz Ibz If you add cornstarch into the mix it will clump. this method is 
called 'introducing'. it means adding a hot mix into a cold. you need to 
make them the same temp so they mix well together. You will see me do this 
in a few recipes. Your second comment is right 'if you add something hot to 
it it will clump', thats why is add a little hot, mix and then add it back 
in. make sense?

comments.text:
+Emma Kachanoski Good question. It is to be 'soft peaks' so when you add in 
the sugar it is 'stabilized' enough to hold the sugar. If you beat the egg 
whites to stiff peaks with no sugar they will kind of separate and dry, not 
good at all. Watch here to see how to make basic meringue  
http://bit.ly/1jMaVZg. Glad you like my accent :).
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:

captions.text: (Music)
Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Lemon Meringue Pie

Hi Bold Bakers! Tomorrow is National Lemon
Meringue Pie Day and a lot of you have been

requesting pie recipes. So this week's recipe
is kind of a no-brainer. I'm making Lemon
Meringue Pie. So let's get baking!

Our first step for this pie is making our
pie crust. We're going to make ours in a food
processor but you can also make it by hand.

In our food processor, we're going to put
in our flour,

icing sugar,
and a pinch of salt for flavor.

Give those ingredients a little stir around
so you mix them well together.

To this add in your cubed cold butter. Now
we're going to put on the lid and pulse it
until it resembles fine bread crumbs.

If you don't have a food processor for this
dough, don't worry. You can rub in the butter
by using your fingertips or by using a fork.

Now that the butter is rubbed in, we're going
to add in our egg and our water.

We're going to turn on the machine and slowly
add it in
until you see the dough start to form.

Form your dough onto your cling film.
Pat it down nice and thin.
And then wrap it up.

We're going to pop this pastry into the fridge
for a minimum 30 minutes

and while it's relaxing we're going to get
started on our lemon curd.

We're going to start out with the main ingredient
for our lemon curd which is these lovely California
lemons that we get.
We're going to zest and juice them.

You can't beat that beautiful fresh citrus
flavor.

To juice your lemons, here's a little tip.
Push it against your surface with the palm

of your hand and try to break down the fibers
on the inside
you get way more juice out!

In a heavy bottomed sauce pan
over medium heat we're going to bring our
lemon juice and sugar to a simmer.

If any of your seeds have made their way into
the lemon juice don't worry about it since
we're going to strain it later.

Now to add in your corn starch, take a little
bit of the hot liquid and mix it with the

corn starch. This is really important to get
it nice and warm. Then we're going to introduce
it back into the pot

Stir it really fast and cook it until it thickens
around two to three minutes.

Now that our mix has thickened, we're going
in with our room temperature eggs and remember

to whisk really fast so the eggs don't cook
on the lemon.

And then in with your butter. This will make
your curd lovely and shiny and creamy.

Now cook this mix further for another 4 minutes
and continually stirring.

As you can see the lemon curd is beautiful
and thick.

And you can't see any cooked eggs. This is
really a foolproof way to make lemon curd.
And your lemon curd is done! It looks beautiful.

So we're going to pass it through a strainer
and let it cool down.

You will see in a lot of recipes when you're
storing your lemon curd to rub butter on the

top and then cover it tight with cling film.
But I have a much easier method. Get an already

buttered butter paper and lay it on top. It
will stop your lemon curd from forming a skin

and keep it nice and protected from the fridge.
Perfect!

Our pastry is nice and relaxed so we're going
to start rolling it out. Roll your pastry
out around a quarter of a centimeter thick.
I like mine nice and thick.
And then line your buttered dish with it.

Gently push it down into the tray using your
fingers. Take care not to tear.

Now lots of people have problems with pastry.
It shrinks, or it falls. What I like to do
is prevent that from happening.

So I leave a nice thick lip of pastry around
the edges.

Once it's baked we're going to shave it clean
off and you're going to have a nice clean
finish.

To stop our pastry from rising up, we're going
to dock it

with a fork and that just means to create
these holes.

So a nice sneaky trick is to get some egg
white

and brush the inside of your pastry shell.
And what this does is when it

bakes it forms a seal so your lemon curd
your chocolate filling. Whatever it is, it's

not going to pour out of your baking tray
because you've just made a nice seal for it.

Now we're going to pop this guy in the freezer.
Not in the fridge. In the freezer. Until he

is solid and then we're going to bake him
off. Trust me, we're going to have a perfect
pie crust at the end.

If you'd like to see more videos from me every
week then give this video a THUMBS UP!

Now that our pie crust are totally frozen
we're going to put them in the oven

And bake them until they're full cooked and
golden brown.

The magic of freezing your pastry shells means
you don't need to mess around with baking

beads. You just freeze it and it stays the
perfect shape.

Run your knife along the top of the baking
tray

and get a nice smooth, professional edge on
your pastry.

The meringue I'm using to top our pies is
from my Raspberry Meringue video and I'm going
to put a link in the description box below.

Now that everything is ready, it's time to
assemble our pie. It's my favorite part!

Fill your pre-baked pie base with your beautiful
homemade lemon curd

The thing I love about this dessert, it's
the best of everything.
It's zesty, it's sweet, it's buttery.
And then scoop on generous amounts of meringue.

Pile your meringue sky high. More is definitely
better!

Then pop them back into the oven for around
eight minutes
until they go golden brown.

Now that is how you celebrate National Lemon
Meringue Pie Day. BIG & BOLD! Don't forget

to subscribe to my channel and I'll see you
back here again next Thursday for more Bigger
Bolder Baking.

title: Mile-High Lemon Meringue Pie with Foolproof Pie Crust Recipe - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 27
